Name | Cinderella  
Also known as | [Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language"): _Cenerentola_ ,  
[French](/wiki/French_language "French language"): _Cendrillon_ ,  
[German](/wiki/German_language "German language"): _Aschenputtel_ ,

Data

_**Cinderella**_ ([Italian](/wiki/Italian_language "Italian language"):
_Cenerentola_ , [French](/wiki/French_language "French language"):
_Cendrillon_ , [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"):
_Aschenputtel_), or _**The Little Glass Slipper**_ , is a [folk
tale](/wiki/Folklore "Folklore") embodying a [myth](/wiki/Myth "Myth")-element
of unjust oppression and triumphant reward. Thousands of variants are known
throughout the world.[1][2] The title character is a young woman living in
unfortunate circumstances, that are suddenly changed to remarkable fortune.
The story of [Rhodopis](/wiki/Rhodopis "Rhodopis"), recounted by the Greek
geographer [Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo") in around 7 BC, about a Greek slave
girl who marries the king of Egypt, is usually considered as the earliest
known variant of the "Cinderella" story.[1][2][3] The first literary European
version of the story was published in [Italy](/wiki/Italy "Italy") by
[Giambattista Basile](/wiki/Giambattista_Basile "Giambattista Basile") in his
_[Pentamerone](/wiki/Pentamerone "Pentamerone")_ in 1634; the most popular
version was published by [Charles Perrault](/wiki/Charles_Perrault "Charles
Perrault") in _[Histoires ou contes du temps
passé](/wiki/Histoires_ou_contes_du_temps_pass%C3%A9 "Histoires ou contes du
temps passé")_ in 1697,[4] and later by the [Brothers
Grimm](/wiki/Brothers_Grimm "Brothers Grimm") in their folk tale collection
_[Grimms' Fairy Tales](/wiki/Grimms%27_Fairy_Tales "Grimms' Fairy Tales")_ in
1812.

Although the story's title and main character's name change in different
languages, in English-language folklore "Cinderella" is the archetypal name.
The word "[Cinderella](https://en.wiktionary.org/wiki/Cinderella
"wikt:Cinderella")" has, by analogy, come to mean one whose attributes were
unrecognized, or one who unexpectedly achieves recognition or success after a
period of obscurity and neglect. The still-popular story of "Cinderella"
continues to influence popular culture internationally, lending plot elements,
[allusions](/wiki/Allusions "Allusions"), and
[tropes](/wiki/Trope_\(literature\) "Trope \(literature\)") to a wide variety
of media. The
[Aarne–Thompson](/wiki/Aarne%E2%80%93Thompson_classification_system
"Aarne–Thompson classification system") system classifies Cinderella as "the
persecuted heroine".

## Ancient versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=1
"Edit section: Ancient versions")]

The [Aarne–Thompson](/wiki/Aarne%E2%80%93Thompson_classification_system
"Aarne–Thompson classification system") system classifies Cinderella as type
510A, "the persecuted heroine".[5]:24-26 Variants of the theme are known
throughout the world.

### European
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: European versions")]

#### Rhodopis[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=3 "Edit
section: Rhodopis")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/e7/Egyptian_sandals%2C_vegetable_fiber_-
_Bata_Shoe_Museum_-_DSC00009.JPG/220px-Egyptian_sandals%2C_vegetable_fiber_-
_Bata_Shoe_Museum_-
_DSC00009.JPG)](/wiki/File:Egyptian_sandals,_vegetable_fiber_-
_Bata_Shoe_Museum_-_DSC00009.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Egyptian_sandals,_vegetable_fiber_-_Bata_Shoe_Museum_-
_DSC00009.JPG "Enlarge")

Pair of ancient leather [sandals](/wiki/Sandals "Sandals") from Egypt

Main article: [Rhodopis](/wiki/Rhodopis "Rhodopis")

The oldest known version of the Cinderella story is the ancient Greek story of
[Rhodopis](/wiki/Rhodopis "Rhodopis"),[3][6] a [Greek](/wiki/Greeks_in_Egypt
"Greeks in Egypt") [courtesan](/wiki/Hetaira "Hetaira") living in the
[colony](/wiki/Colonies_in_antiquity "Colonies in antiquity") of
[Naucratis](/wiki/Naucratis "Naucratis") in [Egypt](/wiki/Ancient_Egypt
"Ancient Egypt"), whose name means "Rosy-Cheeks". The story is first recorded
by the [Greek](/wiki/Ancient_Greece "Ancient Greece") geographer
[Strabo](/wiki/Strabo "Strabo") in his
_[Geographica](/wiki/Geographica_\(Strabo\) "Geographica \(Strabo\)")_ (book
17, 33), probably written around 7 BC or thereabouts:[5]:27

> They tell the fabulous story that, when she was bathing, an eagle snatched
> one of her sandals from her maid and carried it to
> [Memphis](/wiki/Memphis,_Egypt "Memphis, Egypt"); and while the king was
> administering justice in the open air, the eagle, when it arrived above his
> head, flung the sandal into his lap; and the king, stirred both by the
> beautiful shape of the sandal and by the strangeness of the occurrence, sent
> men in all directions into the country in quest of the woman who wore the
> sandal; and when she was found in the city of Naucratis, she was brought up
> to Memphis, became the wife of the king ...[7]

The same story is also later reported by the Roman orator
[Aelian](/wiki/Claudius_Aelianus "Claudius Aelianus") (ca. 175–ca. 235) in his
_Miscellanious History_ , which was written entirely in Greek. Aelian's story
closely resembles the story told by Strabo, but adds that the name of the
pharaoh in question was Psammetichus.[8] Aelian's account indicates that the
story of Rhodopis remained popular throughout
[antiquity](/wiki/Classical_antiquity "Classical antiquity").

[Herodotus](/wiki/Herodotus "Herodotus"), some five centuries before Strabo,
records a popular legend about a possibly-related courtesan named
[Rhodopis](/wiki/Rhodopis_\(hetaera\) "Rhodopis \(hetaera\)") in his
_[Histories](/wiki/Histories_\(Herodotus\) "Histories \(Herodotus\)")_ ,[5]:27
claiming that Rhodopis came from [Thrace](/wiki/Thrace "Thrace"), and was the
slave of Iadmon of [Samos](/wiki/Samos "Samos"), and a fellow-slave of the
story-teller [Aesop](/wiki/Aesop "Aesop") and that she was taken to Egypt in
the time of [Pharaoh](/wiki/Pharaoh "Pharaoh") [Amasis](/wiki/Amasis_II
"Amasis II"), and freed there for a large sum by Charaxus of
[Mytilene](/wiki/Mytilene "Mytilene"), brother of [Sappho](/wiki/Sappho
"Sappho") the lyric poet.[5]:27-28[9]

#### _Le Fresne_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=4
"Edit section: Le Fresne")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/09/Marie_de_France_1.tif/lossy-
page1-220px-Marie_de_France_1.tif.jpg)](/wiki/File:Marie_de_France_1.tif)

[](/wiki/File:Marie_de_France_1.tif "Enlarge")

Illustration of [Marie de France](/wiki/Marie_de_France "Marie de France"),
the author of _Le Fresne_ , from a medieval [illuminated
manuscript](/wiki/Illuminated_manuscript "Illuminated manuscript")

The twelfth-century AD _[lai](/wiki/Lai "Lai")_ of _[Le
Fresne](/wiki/Le_Fresne_\(lai\) "Le Fresne \(lai\)")_ ("The Ash-Tree Girl"),
retold by [Marie de France](/wiki/Marie_de_France "Marie de France"), is a
variant of the "Cinderella" story[5]:41 in which a wealthy noblewoman abandons
her infant daughter at the base of an [ash tree](/wiki/Ash_tree "Ash tree")
outside a nunnery with a ring and [brocade](/wiki/Brocade "Brocade") as tokens
of her identity,[5]:41 because she is one of two twin sisters[5]:41 and the
mother fears that she will be accused of infidelity.[5]:41 The infant is
discovered by the porter, who names her _Fresne_ , meaning "Ash Tree",[5]:41
and she raised by the nuns.[5]:41 After she has attained maturity, a young
nobleman sees her and becomes her lover.[5]:41 The nobleman, however, is
forced to marry a woman of noble birth.[5]:41 Fresne accepts that she will
never marry her beloved,[5]:41 but waits in the wedding chamber as a
handmaiden.[5]:41 She covers the bed with her own brocade,[5]:41 but,
unbeknownst to her, her beloved's bride is actually her twin sister,[5]:41 and
her mother recognizes the brocade as the same one she had given to the
daughter she had abandoned so many years before.[5]:41 Fresne's true parentage
is revealed[5]:41 and, as a result of her noble birth, she is allowed to marry
her beloved,[5]:41 while her twin sister is married to a different
nobleman.[5]:41

_[Cordelia](/wiki/Cordelia "Cordelia")_ by [William Frederick
Yeames](/wiki/William_Frederick_Yeames "William Frederick Yeames") (1888)

Aspects of Cinderella may be derived from the story of
[Cordelia](/wiki/Cordelia_of_Britain "Cordelia of Britain") in [Geoffrey of
Monmouth](/wiki/Geoffrey_of_Monmouth "Geoffrey of Monmouth")'s _[Historia
Regum Britanniae](/wiki/Historia_Regum_Britanniae "Historia Regum
Britanniae")_. Cordelia is the youngest and most virtuous of King [Leir of
Britain](/wiki/Leir_of_Britain "Leir of Britain")'s three daughters, however
her virtue is such that it will not allow her to lie in flattering her father
when he asks, so that he divides up the kingdom between the elder daughters
and leaves Cordelia with nothing. Cordelia marries her love, Aganippus, King
of the [Franks](/wiki/Franks "Franks"), and flees to [Gaul](/wiki/Gaul "Gaul")
where she and her husband raise an army and depose her wicked sisters who have
been misusing their father. Cordelia is finally crowned [Queen of
Britain](/wiki/List_of_legendary_kings_of_Britain "List of legendary kings of
Britain"). However her reign only lasts five years. The story is famously
retold in [Shakespeare](/wiki/William_Shakespeare "William Shakespeare")'s
_[King Lear](/wiki/King_Lear "King Lear")_ , but given a tragic ending.

### Asian versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=6
"Edit section: Asian versions")]

#### _Ye Xian_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=7
"Edit section: Ye Xian")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d4/GebundenerFuss.jpg/220px-
GebundenerFuss.jpg)](/wiki/File:GebundenerFuss.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:GebundenerFuss.jpg "Enlarge")

The story of _Ye Xian_ reflected the admiration for small feet in ancient
China. [Foot binding](/wiki/Foot_binding "Foot binding") later became a common
practice to prevent feet from growing.[10]

A version of the story, _[Ye Xian](/wiki/Ye_Xian "Ye Xian")_ , appeared in
_[Miscellaneous Morsels from Youyang](/wiki/Miscellaneous_Morsels_from_Youyang
"Miscellaneous Morsels from Youyang")_ by [Duan Chengshi](/wiki/Duan_Chengshi
"Duan Chengshi") around 860.[11] In this version, the protagonist is Ye Xian,
a hardworking and lovely girl, who befriends a fish, which is the
reincarnation of her deceased mother.[11] Her stepmother and sister kill the
fish,[11] but Ye Xian saves the bones, which are magic,[11] and they help her
dress appropriately for the New Year Festival.[11] Her stepfamily recognizes
her at the festival, causing her to flee and accidentally lose her
slipper.[11] Afterwards, the king finds her slipper[11] and falls in love with
her (eventually rescuing her from her cruel stepmother).[11] Variants of the
story are also found in many ethnic groups in China.[11]

#### _One Thousand and One
Nights_[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=8 "Edit
section: One Thousand and One Nights")]

Several different variants of the story appear in the medieval _[One Thousand
and One Nights](/wiki/One_Thousand_and_One_Nights "One Thousand and One
Nights")_ , also known as the _Arabian Nights_ , including "The Second
Shaykh's Story", "The Eldest Lady's Tale" and "Abdallah ibn Fadil and His
Brothers", all dealing with the theme of a younger sibling harassed by two
jealous elders. In some of these, the siblings are female, while in others,
they are male. One of the tales, "Judar and His Brethren", departs from the
[happy endings](/wiki/Happy_ending "Happy ending") of previous variants and
reworks the plot to give it a [tragic](/wiki/Tragedy "Tragedy") ending
instead, with the younger brother being poisoned by his elder brothers.[12]

_[The Story of Tam and Cam](/wiki/The_Story_of_Tam_and_Cam "The Story of Tam
and Cam")_ , whose plot is similar to Cinderella, has some significant
differences. Like in Chinese version, The heroine Tấm also has a fish which is
killed by the stepmother and the half-sister, and its bones also give her
clothes.[13] Nonetheless, the later part of the story, after Tấm marries the
king, there is a long "battle" with her stepmother and half-sister.

## Literary
versions[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Literary versions")]

The first written European version of the story was published in Napoli
(Naples), Italy, by [Giambattista Basile](/wiki/Giambattista_Basile
"Giambattista Basile"), in his _[Pentamerone](/wiki/Pentamerone
"Pentamerone")_ (1634). The story itself was based in the [Kingdom of
Naples](/wiki/Kingdom_of_Naples "Kingdom of Naples"), at that time the most
important political and cultural center of [Southern
Italy](/wiki/Southern_Italy "Southern Italy") and among the most influential
capitals in Europe, and written in the [Neapolitan
dialect](/wiki/Neapolitan_Language "Neapolitan Language"). It was later
retold, along with other Basile tales, by [Charles
Perrault](/wiki/Charles_Perrault "Charles Perrault") in _[Histoires ou contes
du temps passé](/wiki/Histoires_ou_contes_du_temps_pass%C3%A9 "Histoires ou
contes du temps passé")_ (1697),[4] and by the [Brothers
Grimm](/wiki/Brothers_Grimm "Brothers Grimm") in their folk tale collection
_[Grimms' Fairy Tales](/wiki/Grimms%27_Fairy_Tales "Grimms' Fairy Tales")_
(1812).

The name "Cenerentola" comes from the Italian word "cenere" – tchenere (ash –
cinder). It has to do with the fact that servants and scullions were usually
soiled with ash at that time, because of their cleaning work and also because
they had to live in cold basements so they usually tried to get warm by
sitting close to the fireplace.

### _Cenerentola_ , by
Basile[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Cenerentola, by Basile")]

[Giambattista Basile](/wiki/Giambattista_Basile "Giambattista Basile"), an
Italian soldier and government official, assembled a set of oral folk tales
into a written collection titled _Lo cunto de li cunti_ (The Story of
Stories), or _[Pentamerone](/wiki/Pentamerone "Pentamerone")_. It included the
tale of Cenerentola, which features a wicked stepmother and evil stepsisters,
magical transformations, a missing slipper, and a hunt by a monarch for the
owner of the slipper. It was published posthumously in 1634.

**Plot:**

    A prince has a daughter, Zezolla (tonnie) (the Cinderella figure), who is tended by a beloved governess. The governess, with Zezolla's help, persuades the prince to marry her. The governess then brings forward six daughters of her own, who abuse Zezolla (tonnie), and send her into the kitchen to work as a servant. The prince goes to the island of Sinia, meets a fairy who gives presents to his daughter, and brings back for her: a golden spade, a golden bucket, a silken napkin, and a date seedling. The girl cultivates the tree, and when the king hosts a ball, Zezolla appears dressed richly by a fairy living in the date tree. The king falls in love with her, but Zezolla runs away before he can find out who she is. Twice Zezolla escapes the king and his servants. The third time, the king's servant captures one of her slippers. The king invites all of the maidens in the land to a ball with a shoe-test, identifies Zezolla (tonnie) after the shoe jumps from his hand to her foot, and eventually marries her.[14]

### _Cendrillon_ , by
Perrault[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=12 "Edit

One of the most popular versions of Cinderella was written in French by
[Charles Perrault](/wiki/Charles_Perrault "Charles Perrault") in 1697, under
the name _Cendrillon_. The popularity of his tale was due to his additions to
the story, including the [pumpkin](/wiki/Pumpkin "Pumpkin"), the fairy-
godmother and the introduction of "glass" slippers.[15]

**Plot:**

    A wealthy widower marries a proud and haughty woman as his second wife. She has two [daughters](/wiki/False_hero "False hero"), who are equally vain and selfish. The gentleman has a beautiful young daughter, a girl of unparalleled kindness and sweet temper. The man's daughter is forced into servitude, where she is made to work day and night doing menial chores. After the girl's chores are done for the day, she curls up near the fireplace in an effort to stay warm. She often arises covered in cinders, giving rise to the mocking nickname "Cinderella" by her stepsisters. Cinderella bears the abuse patiently and does not tell her father, who would have scolded her.
    One day, the Prince invites all the young ladies in the land to a [royal ball](/wiki/Ball_\(dance\) "Ball \(dance\)"), planning to choose a wife. The two [stepsisters](/wiki/Step_family "Step family") gleefully plan their wardrobes for the ball, and taunt Cinderella by telling her that maids are not invited to the ball.
    As the sisters depart to the ball, Cinderella cries in despair. Her [Fairy Godmother](/wiki/Fairy_godmother "Fairy godmother") magically appears and immediately begins to transform Cinderella from house servant to the young lady she was by birth, all in the effort to get Cinderella to the ball. She turns a [pumpkin](/wiki/Pumpkin "Pumpkin") into a golden carriage, [mice](/wiki/Mouse "Mouse") into [horses](/wiki/Horse "Horse"), a [rat](/wiki/Rat "Rat") into a [coachman](/wiki/Coachman "Coachman"), and [lizards](/wiki/Lizard "Lizard") into [footmen](/wiki/Footman "Footman"). She then turns Cinderella's rags into a beautiful jeweled gown, complete with a delicate pair of glass slippers. The Godmother tells her to enjoy the ball, but warns her that she must return before [midnight](/wiki/Midnight "Midnight"), when the [spells](/wiki/Magic_\(paranormal\) "Magic \(paranormal\)") will be broken.
    At the ball, the entire [court](/wiki/Noble_court "Noble court") is entranced by Cinderella, especially the Prince. At this first ball, Cinderella remembers to leave before midnight. Back home, Cinderella graciously thanks her Godmother. She then greets the stepsisters, who had not recognized her earlier, and talk of nothing but the beautiful girl at the ball.
    Another ball is held the next evening, and Cinderella again attends with her Godmother's help. The Prince has become even more infatuated, and Cinderella in turn becomes so enchanted by him she loses track of time and leaves only at the final stroke of midnight, losing one of her glass slippers on the steps of the palace in her haste. The Prince chases her, but outside the palace, the guards see only a simple country girl leave. The Prince pockets the slipper and vows to find and marry the girl to whom it belongs. Meanwhile, Cinderella keeps the other slipper, which does not disappear when the spell is broken.
    The Prince tries the slipper on all the women in the kingdom. When the Prince arrives at Cinderella's home, the stepsisters try in vain to win him over. Cinderella asks if she may try, but the stepsisters taunt her. Naturally, the slipper fits perfectly, and Cinderella produces the other slipper for good measure. Cinderella's stepfamily pleads for forgiveness, and Cinderella agrees.
    Cinderella married the Prince as her stepsisters are married to two handsome gentlemen of the royal court.

The first moral of the story is that beauty is a treasure, but graciousness is
priceless. Without it, nothing is possible; with it, one can do anything.[16]

However, the second moral of the story mitigates the first one and reveals the
criticism that Perrault is aiming at: That "without doubt it is a great
advantage to have intelligence, courage, good breeding, and common sense.
These, and similar talents come only from heaven, and it is good to have them.
However, even these may fail to bring you success, without the blessing of a
godfather or a godmother."[16]

### _Aschenputtel_ , by the Brothers
Grimm[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=13 "Edit
section: Aschenputtel, by the Brothers Grimm")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/64/Aschenputtel.jpg/220px-
Aschenputtel.jpg)](/wiki/File:Aschenputtel.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Aschenputtel.jpg "Enlarge")

[Alexander Zick](/wiki/Alexander_Zick "Alexander Zick") illustrated
_Cinderella with the doves_ , inspired by the Grimms' version.

Another well-known version was recorded by the German brothers [Jacob and
Wilhelm Grimm](/wiki/Brothers_Grimm "Brothers Grimm") in the 19th century. The
tale is called _" Aschenputtel"_ (_" Cinderella"_ in English translations).
This version is much more intense than that of Perrault and Disney, in that
Cinderella's father did not die and the stepsisters mutilate their feet to fit
in the golden slipper. There is no fairy godmother, but rather help comes from
a wishing tree that the heroine planted on her mother's grave. The stepsisters
suffer a terrible punishment for their cruelty.

**Plot:**

    A plague infests a village, and a wealthy gentleman's wife lies on her deathbed. She calls for her only daughter, and tells her to remain good and kind, as God would protect her. She then dies and is buried. The child visits her mother's grave every day to grieve and a year goes by. The gentleman marries another woman with two older daughters from a previous marriage. They have beautiful faces and fair skin, but their hearts are cruel and wicked. The stepsisters steal the girl's fine clothes and jewels and force her to wear rags. They banish her into the kitchen, and give her the nickname "Aschenputtel" ("Ashfool"). She is forced to do all kinds of hard work from dawn to dusk. The cruel sisters will do nothing but mock her and make her chores harder by creating messes. However, despite all of it, the girl remains good and kind, and will always go to her mother's grave to cry and pray to God that she will see her circumstances improve.

    One day the gentleman visits a fair, promising his stepdaughters gifts of luxury. The eldest asks for beautiful dresses, while the younger for pearls and diamonds. His own daughter merely begs for the first twig to knock his hat off on the way. The gentleman goes on his way, and acquires presents for his stepdaughters. While passing a forest he gets a hazel twig, and gives it to his daughter. She plants the twig over her mother's grave, waters it with her tears and over the years, it grows into a glowing hazel tree. The girl prays under it three times a day, and a white bird will always comes to her. She will tell her wishes to the bird, and every time the bird will throw down to her what she has wished for.

    The king decides to ordain a festival that will last for three days and invites all the beautiful maidens in the land to attend so that the prince can select one of them for his bride. The two sisters are also invited, but when Aschenputtel begs them to allow her to go with them into the celebration, the stepmother refuses because she has no decent dress nor shoes to wear. When the girl insists, the woman throws a dish of lentils into the ashes for her to pick up, guaranteeing her permission to attend the festival, if she can clean up the lentils in two hours. When the girl accomplishes the task in less than an hour with the help of a flock of white doves that came when she sings a certain chant, the stepmother only redoubles the task and throws down even a greater quantity of lentils. When Aschenputtel is able to accomplish it in a greater speed, not wanting to spoil her daughters' chances, the stepmother hastens away with her husband and daughters to the celebration and leaves the crying stepdaughter behind.

    The girl retreats to the graveyard and asks to be clothed in silver and gold. The white bird drops a gold and silver gown and silk shoes. She goes to the feast. The prince dances with her all the time, and when sunset comes she asks to leave. The prince escorts her home, but she eludes him and jumps inside the pigeon coop. The father has come home ahead of time and the prince asks him to chop the pigeon coop down, but Aschenputtel has already escaped. The next day, the girl appears in grander apparel. The prince falls in love with her and dances with her for the whole day, and when sunset comes, the prince tries to accompany her home again. However, she climbs a pear tree to escape him. The Prince calls her father who chops down the tree, wondering if it could be Aschenputtel, but Aschenputtel has disappeared. The third day, she appears dressed in the grandest with slippers of gold. Now the prince is determined to keep her, and has the entire stairway smeared with pitch. Aschenputtel loses track of time, and when she runs away one of her golden slippers sticks on that pitch. The prince proclaims that he will marry the maiden whose foot fits the golden slipper.

    The next morning, the prince goes to Aschenputtel's house and tries the slipper on the eldest stepsister. The sister was advised by her mother to cut off her toes in order to fit the slipper. While riding with the stepsister, the two doves from Heaven tell the Prince that blood drips from her foot. Appalled by her treachery, he goes back again and tries the slipper on the other stepsister. She cuts off part of her heel in order to get her foot in the slipper, and again the prince is fooled. While riding with her to the king's castle, the doves alert him again about the blood on her foot. He comes back to inquire about another girl. The gentleman tells him that they keep a kitchen-maid in the house – omitting to mention that she is his own daughter – and the prince asks him to let her try on the slipper. Aschenputtel appears after washing herself, and when she puts on the slipper, the prince recognizes her as the stranger with whom he has danced at the ball.

    In the end, during Aschenputtel's wedding, as she walks down the aisle with her stepsisters as her bridesmaids, (they had hoped to worm their way into her favour), the doves fly down and strike the two stepsisters' eyes, one in the left and the other in the right. When the wedding comes to an end, and Aschenputtel and her prince march out of the church, the doves fly again, striking the remaining eyes of the two evil sisters blind, a punishment they had to endure for the rest of their lives.[17]

Aschenputtel's relationship with her father in this version is ambiguous;
[Perrault](/wiki/Charles_Perrault "Charles Perrault")'s version states that
the absent father is dominated by his second wife, explaining why he does not
prevent the abuse of his daughter. However, the father in this tale plays an
active role in several scenes, and it is not explained why he tolerates the
mistreatment of his child. He also describes Aschenputtel as his "first wife's
child" and not his own.

## Plot variations and alternative
tellings[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=14 "Edit
section: Plot variations and alternative tellings")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/a9/Edward_Burne-
Jones_Cinderella.jpg/220px-Edward_Burne-
Jones_Cinderella.jpg)](/wiki/File:Edward_Burne-Jones_Cinderella.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Edward_Burne-Jones_Cinderella.jpg "Enlarge")

_Cinderella_ by [Edward Burne-Jones](/wiki/Edward_Burne-Jones "Edward Burne-
Jones"), 1863, [Museum of Fine Arts, Boston](/wiki/Museum_of_Fine_Arts,_Boston
"Museum of Fine Arts, Boston")

**Villains:** In some versions, her father plays an active role in the
humiliation of his daughter; in others, he is secondary to his new wife,
Cinderella's stepmother; in some versions, especially the popular [Disney
film](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1950_film\) "Cinderella \(1950 film\)"), Cinderella's
father has died and Cinderella's mother has died also.

Although many variants of Cinderella feature the wicked stepmother, the
defining trait of type [510A](/wiki/Antti_Aarne "Antti Aarne") is a female
persecutor: in _[Fair, Brown and Trembling](/wiki/Fair,_Brown_and_Trembling
"Fair, Brown and Trembling")_ and _[Finette Cendron](/wiki/Finette_Cendron
"Finette Cendron")_ , the stepmother does not appear at all, and it is the
older sisters who confine her to the kitchen. In other fairy tales featuring
the ball, she was driven from home by the persecutions of her father, usually
because he wished to marry her. Of this type (510B) are _[Cap O'
Rushes](/wiki/Cap_O%27_Rushes "Cap O' Rushes")_, _[Catskin](/wiki/Catskin
"Catskin")_ , All-Kinds-of-Fur, and _[Allerleirauh](/wiki/Allerleirauh
"Allerleirauh")_ , and she slaves in the kitchen because she found a job
there.[18] In _[Katie Woodencloak](/wiki/Katie_Woodencloak "Katie
Woodencloak")_ , the stepmother drives her from home, and she likewise finds
such a job.

In _[La Cenerentola](/wiki/La_Cenerentola "La Cenerentola")_ , [Gioachino
Rossini](/wiki/Gioachino_Rossini "Gioachino Rossini") inverted the sex roles:
Cenerentola is oppressed by her [stepfather](/wiki/Stepfamily#stepfathers
"Stepfamily"). (This makes the opera Aarne-Thompson type 510B.) He also made
the economic basis for such hostility unusually clear, in that Don Magnifico
wishes to make his own daughters' [dowries](/wiki/Dowry "Dowry") larger, to
attract a grander match, which is impossible if he must provide a third dowry.
Folklorists often interpret the hostility between the stepmother and
stepdaughter as just such a competition for resources, but seldom does the
tale make it clear.[19]

**Ball, Ballgown, and Curfew:** The number of balls varies, sometimes one,
sometimes two, and sometimes three. The [fairy
godmother](/wiki/Fairy_godmother "Fairy godmother") is Perrault's own addition
to the tale.[20] The person who aided Cinderella (Aschenputtel) in the
[Grimms](/wiki/Brothers_Grimm "Brothers Grimm")'s version is her dead mother.
Aschenputtel requests her aid by praying at her grave, on which a tree is
growing. Helpful doves roosting in the tree shake down the clothing she needs
for the ball. This motif is found in other variants of the tale as well, such
as _The Cinder Maid_ , collected by [Joseph Jacobs](/wiki/Joseph_Jacobs
"Joseph Jacobs"), and the Finnish _[The Wonderful
Birch](/wiki/The_Wonderful_Birch "The Wonderful Birch")_. Playwright [James
Lapine](/wiki/James_Lapine "James Lapine") incorporated this motif into the
Cinderella plotline of the musical _[Into the Woods](/wiki/Into_the_Woods
"Into the Woods")_. [Giambattista Basile](/wiki/Giambattista_Basile
"Giambattista Basile")'s _[Cenerentola](/wiki/Cenerentola "Cenerentola")_
combined them; the Cinderella figure, Zezolla, asks her father to commend her
to the Dove of Fairies and ask her to send her something, and she receives a
tree that will provide her clothing. Other variants have her helped by talking
animals, as in _[Katie Woodencloak](/wiki/Katie_Woodencloak "Katie
Woodencloak")_ , _[Rushen Coatie](/wiki/Rushen_Coatie "Rushen Coatie")_ ,
_[Bawang Putih Bawang Merah](/wiki/Bawang_Putih_Bawang_Merah "Bawang Putih
Bawang Merah")_ , _[The Story of Tam and Cam](/wiki/The_Story_of_Tam_and_Cam
"The Story of Tam and Cam")_ , or _[The Sharp Grey
Sheep](/wiki/The_Sharp_Grey_Sheep "The Sharp Grey Sheep")_ —these animals
often having some connection with her dead mother; in _[The Golden
Slipper](/wiki/The_Golden_Slipper "The Golden Slipper")_ , a fish aids her
after she puts it in water. In "The Anklet", it's a magical alabaster pot the
girl purchased with her own money that brings her the gowns and the anklets
she wears to the ball. [Gioachino Rossini](/wiki/Gioachino_Rossini "Gioachino
Rossini"), having agreed to do an opera based on _Cinderella_ if he could omit
all magical elements, wrote _[La Cenerentola](/wiki/La_Cenerentola "La
Cenerentola")_ , in which she was aided by Alidoro, a philosopher and formerly
the Prince's tutor.

The midnight curfew is also absent in many versions; Cinderella leaves the
ball to get home before her stepmother and stepsisters, or she is simply
tired. In the Grimms' version, Aschenputtel slips away when she is tired,
hiding on her father's estate in a tree, and then the pigeon coop, to elude
her pursuers; her father tries to catch her by chopping them down, but she
escapes.[21]

Furthermore, the gathering need not be a ball; several variants on Cinderella,
such as _Katie Woodencloak_ and _The Golden Slipper_ have her attend church.

In the three-ball version, Cinderella keeps a close watch on the time the
first two nights and is able to leave without difficulty. However, on the
[third](/wiki/Rule_of_three_\(writing\) "Rule of three \(writing\)") (or only)
night, she loses track of the time and must flee the castle before her
disguise vanishes. In her haste, she loses a glass slipper which the prince
finds—or else the prince has carefully had her exit tarred, so as to catch
her, and the slipper is caught in it.

**The identifying item:** The glass slipper is unique to [Charles
Perrault](/wiki/Charles_Perrault "Charles Perrault")'s version and its
derivatives; in other versions of the tale it may be made of other materials
(in the version recorded by the [Brothers Grimm](/wiki/Brothers_Grimm
"Brothers Grimm"), [German](/wiki/German_language "German language"):
_Aschenbroedel_ and _Aschenputtel_ , for instance, it is gold) and in still
other tellings, it is not a slipper but an anklet, a ring, or a bracelet that
gives the prince the key to Cinderella's identity. In Rossini's opera "_[La
Cenerentola](/wiki/La_Cenerentola "La Cenerentola")_ " ("Cinderella"), the
slipper is replaced by twin bracelets to prove her identity. In the Finnish
variant _[The Wonderful Birch](/wiki/The_Wonderful_Birch "The Wonderful
Birch")_ the prince uses tar to gain something every ball, and so has a ring,
a circlet, and a pair of slippers. Interpreters unaware of the value attached
to glass in 17th century France and perhaps troubled by sartorial
impracticalities, have suggested that Perrault's "glass slipper" (_pantoufle
de verre_) had been a "squirrel fur slipper" (_pantoufle de vair_) in some
unidentified earlier version of the tale, and that Perrault or one of his
sources confused the words; however, most scholars believe the glass slipper
was a deliberate piece of poetic invention on Perrault's part.[22] The [1950
Disney adaptation](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1950_film\) "Cinderella \(1950 film\)")
takes advantage of the slipper being made of glass to add a twist whereby the
slipper is shattered just before Cinderella has the chance to try it on,
leaving her with only the matching slipper with which to prove her identity.

Another interpretation of verre/vair (glass/fur) suggested a sexual
element—the Prince was 'trying on' the 'fur slipper' (vagina) of the maidens
in the kingdom, as a '[Droit du seigneur](/wiki/Droit_du_seigneur "Droit du
seigneur")' right of sexual possession of his subjects. The disguised
Cinderella's 'fur slipper' was of unique appeal to the Prince who sought her
thereafter through sexual congress (a variety of sources including Joan
Gould).

The translation of the story into cultures with different standards of beauty
has left the significance of Cinderella's shoe size unclear, and resulted in
the implausibility of Cinderella's feet being of a unique size for no
particular reason. Humorous retellings of the story sometimes use the twist of
having the shoes turn out to also fit somebody completely unsuitable, such as
an amorous old crone. In [Terry Pratchett](/wiki/Terry_Pratchett "Terry
Pratchett")'s _[Witches Abroad](/wiki/Witches_Abroad "Witches Abroad")_ , the
witches accuse another witch of manipulating the events because it was a
common shoe size, and she could only ensure that the right woman put it on if
she already knew where she was and went straight to her. In "When the Clock
Strikes" (from _[Red As
Blood](/w/index.php?title=Red_As_Blood&action=edit&redlink=1 "Red As Blood
\(page does not exist\)")_), [Tanith Lee](/wiki/Tanith_Lee "Tanith Lee") had
the sorcerous shoe alter shape whenever a woman tried to put it on, so it
would not fit.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/Gustave_dore_cendrillon4.JPG/220px-
Gustave_dore_cendrillon4.JPG)](/wiki/File:Gustave_dore_cendrillon4.JPG)

[](/wiki/File:Gustave_dore_cendrillon4.JPG "Enlarge")

Cinderella tries on the slipper

**The Revelation:** Cinderella's stepmother and [stepsisters](/wiki/False_hero
"False hero") (in some versions just the stepsisters and, in some other
versions, a stepfather and stepsisters) conspire to win the prince's hand for
one of them. In the German telling, the first stepsister fits into the slipper
by cutting off a toe, but the doves in the hazel tree alert the prince to the
blood dripping from the slipper, and he returns the false bride to her mother.
The second stepsister fits into the slipper by cutting off her heel, but the
same doves give her away.

In many variants of the tale, the prince is told that Cinderella can not
possibly be the one, as she is too dirty and ragged. Often, this is said by
the stepmother or stepsisters. In the Grimms' version, both the stepmother and
the father urge it.[23] The prince nevertheless insists on her trying.
Cinderella arrives and proves her identity by fitting into the slipper or
other item (in some cases she has kept the other).

**The Conclusion:** In the German version of the story, the evil stepsisters
are punished for their deception by having their eyes pecked out by birds. In
other versions, they are forgiven, and made ladies-in-waiting with marriages
to lesser lords.

In [The Thousand Nights and A
Night](/wiki/The_Book_of_One_Thousand_and_One_Nights "The Book of One Thousand
and One Nights"), in a tale called "The Anklet",[24] the stepsisters make a
comeback by using twelve magical hairpins to turn the bride into a dove on her
wedding night. In _[The Wonderful Birch](/wiki/The_Wonderful_Birch "The
Wonderful Birch")_ , the stepmother, a witch, manages to substitute her
daughter for the true bride after she has given birth. Such tales continue the
fairy tale into what is in effect a second episode.

In an episode of [Jim Henson](/wiki/Jim_Henson "Jim Henson")'s _[The
Storyteller](/wiki/The_Storyteller_\(TV_series\) "The Storyteller \(TV
series\)")_ , writer [Anthony Minghella](/wiki/Anthony_Minghella "Anthony
Minghella") merged the old folk tale _[Donkeyskin](/wiki/Donkeyskin
"Donkeyskin")_ (also written by Perrault) with _Cinderella_ to tell the tale
of _Sapsorrow_ , a girl both cursed and blessed by destiny.

Many popular new works based on the story feature one step-sister who is not
as cruel to Cinderella as the other. Examples are the film _Ever After_ ,
_Cinderella 3_ and the Broadway revival.

## Folkloristics[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=15
"Edit section: Folkloristics")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/d2/Cendrillon2_crop.jpg/220px-
Cendrillon2_crop.jpg)](/wiki/File:Cendrillon2_crop.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Cendrillon2_crop.jpg "Enlarge")

Cinderella or Cendrillon in French. Detail from [Gustave
Doré](/wiki/Gustave_Dor%C3%A9 "Gustave Doré")'s illustration for _Cendrillon_

Folklorists have long studied variants on this tale across cultures.[25] In
1893, [Marian Roalfe Cox](/wiki/Marian_Roalfe_Cox "Marian Roalfe Cox"),
commissioned by [the Folklore Society](/wiki/The_Folklore_Society "The
Folklore Society") of Britain, produced _Cinderella: Three Hundred and Forty-
Five Variants of Cinderella, Catskin and, Cap o 'Rushes, Abstracted and
Tabulated with a Discussion of Medieval Analogues and Notes._[25]

Further [morphology](/wiki/Morphology_\(folkloristics\) "Morphology
\(folkloristics\)") studies have continued on this seminal work.[25]

The [Aarne–Thompson](/wiki/Aarne%E2%80%93Thompson_classification_system
"Aarne–Thompson classification system") system classifies _Cinderella_ as type
510A, "the persecuted heroine". Others of this type include _[The Sharp Grey
Sheep](/wiki/The_Sharp_Grey_Sheep "The Sharp Grey Sheep")_ ; _[The Golden
Slipper](/wiki/The_Golden_Slipper "The Golden Slipper")_ ; _[The Story of Tam
and Cam](/wiki/The_Story_of_Tam_and_Cam "The Story of Tam and Cam")_ ;
_[Rushen Coatie](/wiki/Rushen_Coatie "Rushen Coatie")_ ; _[The Wonderful
Birch](/wiki/The_Wonderful_Birch "The Wonderful Birch")_ ; _[Fair, Brown and
Trembling](/wiki/Fair,_Brown_and_Trembling "Fair, Brown and Trembling")_ ; and
_[Katie Woodencloak](/wiki/Katie_Woodencloak "Katie Woodencloak")_.[26]

The story of Cinderella has formed the basis of many notable works:

### Opera and
ballet[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=17 "Edit
section: Opera and ballet")]

  * _Cendrillon_ (1749) by [Jean-Louis Laruette](/w/index.php?title=Jean-Louis_Laruette&action=edit&redlink=1 "Jean-Louis Laruette \(page does not exist\)")
  * _[Cendrillon](/wiki/Cendrillon_\(Isouard\) "Cendrillon \(Isouard\)")_ (1810) by [Nicolas Isouard](/wiki/Nicolas_Isouard "Nicolas Isouard"), libretto by [Charles-Guillaume Étienne](/wiki/Charles-Guillaume_%C3%89tienne "Charles-Guillaume Étienne")
  * _[La Cenerentola](/wiki/La_Cenerentola "La Cenerentola")_ (1817) by [Gioachino Rossini](/wiki/Gioachino_Rossini "Gioachino Rossini")
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(Fitinhof-Schell\) "Cinderella \(Fitinhof-Schell\)")_ (1893) by Baron Boris Vietinghoff-Scheel
  * _[Cendrillon](/wiki/Cendrillon "Cendrillon")_ (1894–5) by [Jules Massenet](/wiki/Jules_Massenet "Jules Massenet"), libretto by [Henri Caïn](/wiki/Henri_Ca%C3%AFn "Henri Caïn")
  * _[Cendrillon](/wiki/Cendrillon_\(Viardot\) "Cendrillon \(Viardot\)")_ (1904) by [Pauline García-Viardot](/wiki/Pauline_Garc%C3%ADa-Viardot "Pauline García-Viardot")
  * _[La Cenicienta](/wiki/La_Cenicienta "La Cenicienta")_ (1966) by [Jorge Peña Hen](/wiki/Jorge_Pe%C3%B1a_Hen "Jorge Peña Hen")
  * _[Aschenbrödel](/wiki/Aschenbr%C3%B6del "Aschenbrödel")_ (1901) by [Johann Strauss II](/wiki/Johann_Strauss_II "Johann Strauss II"), adapted and completed by [Josef Bayer](/wiki/Josef_Bayer "Josef Bayer")
  * _Soluschka_ or _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(Prokofiev\) "Cinderella \(Prokofiev\)")_ (1945) by [Sergei Prokofiev](/wiki/Sergei_Prokofiev "Sergei Prokofiev")

### Theatre[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=18 "Edit
section: Theatre")]

  * _Cinderella_ debuted as a [pantomime](/wiki/Pantomime "Pantomime") on stage at the [Drury Lane Theatre](/wiki/Theatre_Royal,_Drury_Lane "Theatre Royal, Drury Lane"), [London](/wiki/London "London") in 1904 and at the [Adelphi Theatre](/wiki/Adelphi_Theatre "Adelphi Theatre") in London in 1905. [Phyllis Dare](/wiki/Phyllis_Dare "Phyllis Dare"), aged 14 or 15, starred in the latter. In the traditional pantomime version the opening scene takes place in a forest with a hunt in progress; here Cinderella first meets Prince Charming and his "right-hand man" Dandini, whose name and character come from [Gioachino Rossini](/wiki/Gioachino_Rossini "Gioachino Rossini")'s opera (_[La Cenerentola](/wiki/La_Cenerentola "La Cenerentola")_). Cinderella mistakes Dandini for the Prince and the Prince for Dandini. Her father, Baron Hardup, is under the thumb of his two stepdaughters, the [Ugly sisters](/wiki/Ugly_sisters "Ugly sisters"), and has a servant, Cinderella's friend [Buttons](/wiki/Buttons_\(pantomime\) "Buttons \(pantomime\)"). (Throughout the pantomime, the Baron is continually harassed by the Broker's Men (often named after current politicians) for outstanding rent.) The Fairy Godmother must magically create a coach (from a pumpkin), footmen (from mice), a coach driver (from a frog), and a beautiful dress (from rags) for Cinderella to go to the ball. However, she must return by midnight, as it is then that the spell ceases.
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(musical\) "Cinderella \(musical\)")_ by [Rodgers and Hammerstein](/wiki/Rodgers_and_Hammerstein "Rodgers and Hammerstein") was produced for television three times and staged live. A version ran in 1958 at the [London Coliseum](/wiki/London_Coliseum "London Coliseum") with a cast including [Tommy Steele](/wiki/Tommy_Steele "Tommy Steele"), Yana, [Jimmy Edwards](/wiki/Jimmy_Edwards "Jimmy Edwards"), [Kenneth Williams](/wiki/Kenneth_Williams "Kenneth Williams") and [Betty Marsden](/wiki/Betty_Marsden "Betty Marsden"). This version was augmented with several other [Rodgers and Hammerstein](/wiki/Rodgers_and_Hammerstein "Rodgers and Hammerstein")'s songs plus a song written by Tommy Steele, "You and Me". In 2013, the musical debuted its first [Broadway production](/wiki/Cinderella_\(2013_Broadway_production\) "Cinderella \(2013 Broadway production\)") with a new book by [Douglas Carter Beane](/wiki/Douglas_Carter_Beane "Douglas Carter Beane").
  * _[Mr. Cinders](/wiki/Mr._Cinders "Mr. Cinders")_ , a musical which opened at the [Adelphi Theatre](/wiki/Adelphi_Theatre "Adelphi Theatre"), London in 1929. Filmed in 1934
  * _[Into the Woods](/wiki/Into_the_Woods "Into the Woods")_ , music and lyrics by [Stephen Sondheim](/wiki/Stephen_Sondheim "Stephen Sondheim") and book by [James Lapine](/wiki/James_Lapine "James Lapine"), a musical in which Cinderella is one of many fairy-tale characters who take part in the plot. This is partly based on the Grimm Brothers' version of "Cinderella", including the enchanted birds, mother's grave, three balls, and mutilation and blinding of the stepsisters. It opened on Broadway in 1988.
  * _[Cindy](/wiki/Cindy_\(musical\) "Cindy \(musical\)")_ , a 1964 [Off-Broadway](/wiki/Off-Broadway "Off-Broadway") musical composed by [Johnny Brandon](/wiki/Johnny_Brandon "Johnny Brandon")
  * _Cinderella_ ; book by Jim Eiler; Music by Jim Eiler and Jeanne Bargy; Lyrics by Jim Eiler[27]
  * _Cinderella_ ; book by Norman Robbins; lyrics by Amy Powers and Dan Levy; music by Dan Levy; opened [Off Broadway](/wiki/Off_Broadway "Off Broadway") December 19, 1991 at Playhouse 91[28]
  * Bonnie Lythgoe Productions presented the musical pantomime at the [State Theatre](/wiki/State_Theatre_\(Sydney\) "State Theatre \(Sydney\)") in [Sydney](/wiki/Sydney "Sydney"), [Australia](/wiki/Australia "Australia") from 1 to 17 July 2016. It was described as "the ultimate winter feel good panto to charm audiences of all ages. This magical rags to riches story will feature sumptuous glittering sets, gorgeous fairytale costumes, fantastic song and dance numbers, infectious and riotous comedy magic and bags of audience participation. Fun and laughter is guaranteed for the whole family!" by the official website.[29]
  * Cinderella by Shadow theatre Delight[30] The first time was shown on the stage in 2016 in the city of Chernihiv Ukraine

### Films and
television[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Cinderella&action=edit&section=19 "Edit
section: Films and television")]

![File:Cinderella
\(1911\).webm](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/Cinderella_%281911%29.webm/220px-
seek%3D1-Cinderella_%281911%29.webm.jpg)[Play
media](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/9/9a/Cinderella_%281911%29.webm
"Play media")

[](/wiki/File:Cinderella_\(1911\).webm "Enlarge")

_Cinderella_ (1911)

Over the decades, hundreds of films have been made that are either direct
adaptations from Cinderella or have plots loosely based on the story.

  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1899_film\) "Cinderella \(1899 film\)")_ (1899), the first film version, produced in France by [Georges Méliès](/wiki/Georges_M%C3%A9li%C3%A8s "Georges Méliès"), as "Cendrillon".
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1914_film\) "Cinderella \(1914 film\)")_ (1914), a silent film starring [Mary Pickford](/wiki/Mary_Pickford "Mary Pickford")
  * _Aschenputtel_ (1922), a [silhouette shadow play](/wiki/Silhouette_animation "Silhouette animation") short by [Lotte Reiniger](/wiki/Lotte_Reiniger "Lotte Reiniger").[31] The short silent film uses exaggerated figures and has no background, which creates a stark look. The film shows Aschenputtel's step-sisters graphically hacking their feet off in order to fit into the glass slipper.
  * _Cinderella_ (1922), an animated [Laugh-O-Gram](/wiki/Laugh-O-Gram_Studio "Laugh-O-Gram Studio") produced by [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney"), first released on December 6, 1922. This film was about seven and half minutes long.
  * _[Ella Cinders](/wiki/Ella_Cinders "Ella Cinders")_ (1926), a modern tale starring [Colleen Moore](/wiki/Colleen_Moore "Colleen Moore"), based on a comic strip by [William M. Conselman](/wiki/William_M._Conselman "William M. Conselman") and [Charles Plumb](/wiki/Charles_Plumb "Charles Plumb"), inspired by Charles Perrault's version.
  * _[Cinderella Blues](/wiki/Cinderella_Blues "Cinderella Blues")_ (1931), a [Van Beuren](/wiki/Van_Beuren_Studios "Van Beuren Studios") animated short film featuring a feline version of the Cinderella character.
  * _[Poor Cinderella](/wiki/Poor_Cinderella "Poor Cinderella")_ (1934), [Fleischer Studios](/wiki/Fleischer_Studios "Fleischer Studios")' first color cartoon and only appearance of [Betty Boop](/wiki/Betty_Boop "Betty Boop") in color during the Fleischer era.
  * _[Cinderella Meets Fella](/wiki/Cinderella_Meets_Fella "Cinderella Meets Fella")_ (1938), a [Merrie Melodies](/wiki/Merrie_Melodies "Merrie Melodies") animated short film featuring Egghead, the character who would eventually evolve into [Elmer Fudd](/wiki/Elmer_Fudd "Elmer Fudd"), as Prince Charming.[32]
  * _[Mamele](/wiki/Mamele "Mamele")_ (1938) a [Molly Picon](/wiki/Molly_Picon "Molly Picon") vehicle made by the prewar Warsaw Yiddish film industry taking place in contemporary [Lodz](/wiki/Lodz "Lodz").
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1947_film\) "Cinderella \(1947 film\)")_ (1947), a [Soviet](/wiki/Soviet "Soviet") film based on the screenplay by [Evgeny Schwartz](/wiki/Evgeny_Schwartz "Evgeny Schwartz"), with [Yanina Zhejmo](/wiki/Yanina_Zhejmo "Yanina Zhejmo") in the leading role. Shot black-and-white, it went through [colorization](/wiki/Film_colorization "Film colorization") in 2009.
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1950_film\) "Cinderella \(1950 film\)")_ (1950), a [Walt Disney](/wiki/Walt_Disney "Walt Disney") animated feature released on February 15, 1950, now considered one of [Disney](/wiki/The_Walt_Disney_Company "The Walt Disney Company")'s classics as well as the most well known film adaptation.
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(musical\) "Cinderella \(musical\)")_ (1957), a musical adaptation by [Rodgers and Hammerstein](/wiki/Rodgers_and_Hammerstein "Rodgers and Hammerstein"), starring [Julie Andrews](/wiki/Julie_Andrews "Julie Andrews") as Cinderella, featuring [Jon Cypher](/wiki/Jon_Cypher "Jon Cypher"), [Kaye Ballard](/wiki/Kaye_Ballard "Kaye Ballard"), [Alice Ghostley](/wiki/Alice_Ghostley "Alice Ghostley"), and [Edie Adams](/wiki/Edie_Adams "Edie Adams") (originally broadcast in color, but only black-and-white [kinescopes](/wiki/Kinescope "Kinescope") survive).
  * _[Three Wishes for Cinderella (Tři oříšky pro Popelku)](/wiki/T%C5%99i_o%C5%99%C3%AD%C5%A1ky_pro_Popelku "Tři oříšky pro Popelku")_ (1973), a Czechoslovakian/East German fairy tale film starring Libuše Šafránková as Cinderella and Pavel Trávníček as Prince.[33] A cult film in several European countries.
  * _[Cindy](/wiki/Cindy_\(film\) "Cindy \(film\)")_ (1978), This version of the Cinderella tale with an all-black cast has Cinderella, who wants to marry a dashing army officer, finding out that her father, who she thought had an important job at a big hotel, is actually the men's room attendant. Her wicked stepmother finds out, too, and complications ensue. Starred [Charlayne Woodard](/wiki/Charlayne_Woodard "Charlayne Woodard").
  * _Aschenputtel_ (1989), a television adaptation based on the Grimm Brothers' version.[34]
  * _If The Shoe Fits_ (1990), a modern Cinderella in Paris.[35]
  * _[Cinderella Monogatari](/wiki/The_Story_of_Cinderella "The Story of Cinderella")_ (_The Story of Cinderella_) (1996), anime television series produced by [Tatsunoko Production](/wiki/Tatsunoko_Production "Tatsunoko Production").
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1997_film\) "Cinderella \(1997 film\)")_ (1997), Rodgers and Hammerstein musical starring [Brandy Norwood](/wiki/Brandy_Norwood "Brandy Norwood") as Cinderella, [Whitney Houston](/wiki/Whitney_Houston "Whitney Houston") as the Fairy Godmother, [Bernadette Peters](/wiki/Bernadette_Peters "Bernadette Peters") as Cinderella's evil stepmother, [Jason Alexander](/wiki/Jason_Alexander "Jason Alexander") as Lionel the valet and [Whoopi Goldberg](/wiki/Whoopi_Goldberg "Whoopi Goldberg") as the Queen. Remake of the 1957 and 1965 TV films.
  * _[Ever After](/wiki/Ever_After "Ever After")_ (1998), starring [Drew Barrymore](/wiki/Drew_Barrymore "Drew Barrymore"), a post-feminist, historical fiction take on the Cinderella story.
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(2000_film\) "Cinderella \(2000 film\)")_ , a British modernization featuring Marcella Plunkett as Cinderella, [Kathleen Turner](/wiki/Kathleen_Turner "Kathleen Turner") as the stepmother and [Jane Birkin](/wiki/Jane_Birkin "Jane Birkin") as the fairy godmother.
  * _[Once Upon a Time](/wiki/Once_Upon_a_Time_\(TV_series\) "Once Upon a Time \(TV series\)")_ (2011), features Cinderella as a recurring character, played by [Jessy Schram](/wiki/Jessy_Schram "Jessy Schram") who made a deal with Rumplestiltskin who killed her fairy godmother right in front of her. In 2016, more of the story is shown in which Ashley, Cinderella's real-world counterpart, discovers her stepsister wanted to marry the footman rather than the prince. A different Cinderella in season 7, played by [Dania Ramirez](/wiki/Dania_Ramirez "Dania Ramirez"), went to the ball to kill the prince, not meet him.
  * _[Rags (film)](/wiki/Rags_\(2012_film\) "Rags \(2012 film\)")_ (2012), a musical gender switched inversion of the Cinderella story that stars [Keke Palmer](/wiki/Keke_Palmer "Keke Palmer") and [Max Schneider](/wiki/Max_Schneider "Max Schneider").
  * _[Into the Woods](/wiki/Into_the_Woods_\(film\) "Into the Woods \(film\)")_ (2014), a live-action fairy-tale-themed adaptation of the above-mentioned homonymous musical play, in which [Anna Kendrick](/wiki/Anna_Kendrick "Anna Kendrick")'s Cinderella is a central character.
  * _[Cinderella](/wiki/Cinderella_\(2015_Disney_film\) "Cinderella \(2015 Disney film\)")_ (2015), a live-action film starring [Lily James](/wiki/Lily_James "Lily James") as Cinderella, [Cate Blanchett](/wiki/Cate_Blanchett "Cate Blanchett") as Lady Tremaine, Cinderella's evil stepmother, [Richard Madden](/wiki/Richard_Madden "Richard Madden") as Kit, the Prince Charming and [Helena Bonham Carter](/wiki/Helena_Bonham_Carter "Helena Bonham Carter") as the Fairy Godmother. It is essentially a live-action remake of the [1950 animated film](/wiki/Cinderella_\(1950_film\) "Cinderella \(1950 film\)").
  * Cinderella adaptations on TV and in cinema are not just limited to female protagonists. The _[Sesame Street](/wiki/Sesame_Street "Sesame Street")_ special "[Cinderelmo](/wiki/Cinderelmo "Cinderelmo")" and the _[Magic Adventures of Mumfie](/wiki/Magic_Adventures_of_Mumfie "Magic Adventures of Mumfie")_ episode "Scarecrowella" both feature a male protagonist playing the Cinderella role.
